title: Appraisals and Evaluations - Appraisal and Evaluation Review

json.text: - Hello. I'm Kristie Elmquist, and with me is Barry Aldridge.
In this segment, we concentrate on the review process
for appraisals and evaluations.
The Dodd-Frank Wall Street
Reform and Consumer Protection Act
reinforced the importance of appraisal review.
It amended the Financial Institutions Reform,
Recovery and Enforcement Act and requires the regulatory
agencies to establish a rule that appraisals for federally
related transactions be reviewed for compliance
with the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice,
which we will refer to as USPAP.
At the time this video was created,
the appraisal review rule has not yet been finalized.
Until the rule is final, you should refer to Section XV
of the Interagency Appraisal and Evaluation Guidelines,
which we will refer to as the Interagency Guidelines,
for expectations regarding the review of both appraisals
and evaluations.
Let's talk about the USPAP definition
of "appraisal review."
It is defined as--
which may include the reviewer developing
his or her own opinion of value."
Section XV of the Interagency Guidelines highlights that
"As part of the credit approval process and prior to a final
credit decision, a bank should review appraisals
and evaluations to ensure that they comply with the Agencies'
appraisal regulations and are consistent with supervisory
guidance and its own internal policies."
In other words, to comply with the Interagency Guidelines,
the proposed real estate transaction cannot be approved
until a review determines that the appraisal or evaluation is
acceptable.
Through the review process, a bank should determine
the reasonableness of the appraisal or evaluation,
including whether the methods, assumptions, and data sources
are appropriate and the value conclusion is supported.
The review should be documented and included
in the loan package or loan file.
When a bank's review process identifies an appraisal
or evaluation that is inconsistent with appraisal
regulations and the deficiencies cannot be
resolved, the bank must obtain an appraisal or evaluation
that meets regulatory requirements prior to making
a credit decision.
A reviewer cannot change the value conclusion
in the original appraisal.
However, there is one exception.
An appraisal review performed by a State-certified
or State-licensed appraiser, in accordance with USPAP,
may result in the reviewer developing his or her own
opinion of market value.
This second opinion of market value could be used to support
a bank's credit decision.
- The Interagency Guidelines state that an institution's
policies and procedures for reviewing appraisals
and evaluations, should, at a minimum,
include four main areas.
The first area relates to the reviewer's qualifications.
The policy should establish qualification criteria
for who is eligible to review appraisals and evaluations.
Factors to be assessed include education, expertise,
and competence to perform the review commensurate
with the complexity of the transaction,
type of property, and the market.
The reviewer also should be independent of the transaction
and have no direct or indirect interest, financial
or otherwise, in the property or transaction,
and be independent from the loan production staff.
Small or rural institutions, or branches with limited staff,
should implement prudent safeguards
when absolute lines of independence cannot be achieved.
Independence is one of the topics that we frequently
receive questions about from bankers.
Regarding independence, the Interagency Guidelines note
that, for small or rural banks with limited staff, the review
may be part of the originating loan officer's overall credit
analysis, as long as the originating loan officer
abstains from directly or indirectly approving or voting
to approve the loan.
Additionally, another lender, officer, employee or director
could perform the review, as long as he or she is qualified
and abstains from directly or indirectly approving or voting
to approve the loan.
For any institution, for transactions involving complex
projects that are high-risk, or involve out-of-market
properties, a review by a third party may be more appropriate.
The second area to be addressed by policies
and procedures relates to the depth of the review.
Banks should implement a risk-focused approach
for determining the depth of the review needed to ensure
the appraisal or evaluation contains sufficient
information and analysis to support the credit decision.
The policies should address the depth of review needed
in various circumstances, such as for commercial real estate,
1-to-4 family residential real estate, and when appraisals
are received from other financial institutions.
In the case of commercial real estate, the depth of review
should align with the complexity of the property
and the risk of the loan.
For complex properties or high-risk commercial loans,
the technical quality of the analysis should be closely
reviewed.
For commercial properties securing lower-risk
transactions, or less complex properties, the review may be
less technical in nature.
A bank should establish criteria for when to expand
the depth of the review.
Regarding the depth of review of appraisals or evaluations
of 1-to-4 family residential real estate, the reviews
should reflect a risk-focused approach.
Risk factors could include debt-to-income
and loan-to-value ratios, level of documentation,
dollar amount of the loan, or other risk factors.
With prior approval from its primary Federal banking
regulator, a bank may employ techniques, such as automated
tools or sampling methods, for performing pre-funding reviews
of appraisals or evaluations that support lower-risk
mortgages.
When using these techniques, the bank should maintain
sufficient data and employ appropriate screening parameters
to provide quality assurance.
There are circumstances where banks can use appraisals
obtained from other financial institutions for underwriting
purposes.
These appraisals should be subject to at least the same
level of review that the bank performs on appraisals
it obtains directly for similar properties and the review
should be documented in the credit file.
The bank should confirm that the appraiser was engaged
directly by the other financial institution, and
the appraiser had no direct or indirect interest
in the property or transaction.
- The third area of the policies and procedures requirements
on appraisal and evaluation review relates to
the resolution of deficiencies.
A bank should establish policies and procedures
for resolving any inaccuracies or weaknesses in an appraisal
or evaluation identified during the review.
The fourth area of the policies and procedures
requirements relates to the documentation of the review.
The bank's policies should require documentation
of the review of appraisals and evaluations
in the credit file.
The level of documentation is dependent upon the type, risk,
and complexity of the transaction.
For smaller-dollar loans secured by noncomplex real estate,
documentation of the review can be very brief
if no issues are identified.
The documentation should provide an audit trail
describing the resolution of the noted deficiencies
or the reasons for obtaining and relying on a second appraisal
or evaluation, if that was the result of the review.
- Now that we've covered the requirements for policies
and procedures involving appraisal and evaluation review,
let's go over a few frequently asked questions on the appraisal
review process.
The first question involves a situation where an appraisal
review is conducted by the lead bank for a participation
real estate loan.
A copy of the appraisal and the appraisal review
are forwarded to your bank as a participating bank.
In this situation, is your bank required to perform
an appraisal review?
The answer is yes.
Each bank participating in the credit
should perform an appraisal review to the same extent
that it would review appraisals it obtains directly.
Another question is whether a qualified individual, acting
in the capacity of a reviewer, can change the market value
in the original appraisal or evaluation under review?
The answer is no.
A reviewer cannot change the value conclusion
in the original appraisal or an evaluation.
However, an appraisal review performed by a competent
State-certified or State-licensed appraiser,
in accordance with USPAP, may result in the reviewer
developing his or her own opinion of value.
This value conclusion becomes a second opinion of market value
and can be used for the credit decision.
However, the decision to do so must be documented
in the credit file.
Another question is, "Can a lender assist in preparing
a review for an evaluation or appraisal if the loan
is subject to review by a Loan Committee?"
To maintain independence, loan production staff generally
should not review an appraisal or evaluation.
However, the Interagency Guidelines do provide
clarification that bank insiders, such as another loan
officer, other officer, or director, can be involved
in the review process for a small or rural institution
or branch, if absolute lines of independence cannot be achieved.
In such cases, prudent safeguards should be
established to isolate the activity from the loan
production process.
For example, the bank insider participating in the review
of an appraisal or evaluation must abstain from directly
or indirectly approving or voting to approve the loan.
While banks can handle many reviews in-house, for complex
or high-risk transactions, some banks choose to obtain
the services of a third party to perform the review
of an appraisal or evaluation.
The hiring of a third party can help ensure
that the review activity is performed by an individual
with sufficient expertise to perform the review and helps
to avoid any potential conflict of interest.
- Another question we've received asks about
what kind of communication is permissible between a banker
and an appraiser during the engagement or review
of an appraisal?
Examples of permitted communication include:
providing information to identify the property
and rights being appraised, including legal description,
personal property and development plans;
providing a copy of the sales contract;
asking that additional information be considered,
including information about comparable properties,
to make or support a valuation;
requesting additional detail, substantiation,
or explanation of the value conclusion;
and asking that errors be corrected.
Examples of inappropriate communication include:
- As we have discussed, an appropriate valuation review
program is an important part of the credit approval process.
The review process will assess the reasonableness of
the appraisal or evaluation and ensure compliance with Federal
regulations, supervisory guidance, and a bank's
internal valuation policies.
The review process should be incorporated into a bank's
policies and, at a minimum, should:
For additional information on reviewing appraisals
and evaluations, please refer to Section XV of the Interagency
Guidelines.
In addition, the Winter 2011 edition of the FDIC
Supervisory Insights contains an article entitled
"Navigating the Real Estate Valuation Process."
This article discusses practices that can help banks
employ a more effective valuation review process.
This concludes our segment on
Appraisal and Evaluation Review.
